One of the best games I've ever played. It's raw, hard and sometimes unforgiving, but always exciting. It has a bunch of great characters, good guys and bad guys alike. The facial expressions, especially during cutscenes, are excellent and the same can be said for the voice acting. The landscapes and the changing weather conditions are truly amazing. And the first time you cross paths with a horde... oh, my goodness... it's the stuff of nightmares.

But regardless of how much I like the game, I do have some (mild) criticism as well.

Overlapping conversations is one of them. Sometimes people talk over each other and that makes it hard to follow, even with subtitles on. Your main character, Deacon St. John, has a habit of doing this.

Stories from missions that update throughout your playthrough is another one. You'll get notifications when they update and I'd love to read it all, but they usually pop up at inconvenient times.  Who's going to pause the game to read them while you're in the middle of a gunfight? That just takes you out of the action. So that's badly done. Also, stories aren't always in chronological order. Some current events are logged behind past events, so if you decide to read everything later, it can get a bit confusing.

There's no way to turn off hints. They're welcome when you first start playing the game, but they still appear when you start a New Game Plus and by that time, you really don't need them anymore.

Last but certainly not least, there's too much swearing in this game. I get it, Deacon St. John is a rough biker guy who's been through a lot, but I still don't appreciate it. Yes, I don't always control my emotions either and use bad language too, but no matter how you spin it, it's aggressive and unattractive. If people are constantly swearing in real life, I don't associate with them. I like my video game hero to have some manners. Bad language is a trend in modern day video games that needs to die.

Other than that, to conclude it on a positive note, I had loads of fun playing, upgrading my skills and my motorcycle and taking out threats in various ways.

And naturally, Romero rewarded me with years of recurring nightmares that somehow evolved into a lifelong obsession. Thanks, George.

Because of that obsession, I‚Äôve seen every flavor of zombie media ‚Äî and believe me, a lot of it is flat-out bad. So I hesitated on Days Gone. I heard the PC controls were questionable, and that there were ‚Äúsuper zombies,‚Äù which usually means developers don‚Äôt understand that a slow, relentless horde is already terrifying when written well.

Then I finally played it‚Ä¶ for about 145 hours. And every one of those hours was worth it.

Yes, there are mutated ‚Äúsuper‚Äù variants ‚Äî welcome to modern zombie design ‚Äî but the world is so well built that it still works. And the core idea of the undead being an endless, tireless threat is very much intact.

The graphics are excellent. Cruising around on your motorcycle never stopped being fun. The RPG-style progression was surprisingly satisfying: as the story moved forward, so did you ‚Äî and your bike. Tracking down the injectors was one of my favorite parts because they forced you to think about your playstyle instead of just blindly leveling up. Add in the usual carrot-chasing ‚Äî better guns, better gear ‚Äî and it genuinely felt like you were becoming more capable as the story deepened.

The music? Fantastic.
Voice acting? Top tier.
World design? Easily the highlight.

Even the little points of interest scattered around the map felt deliberate. And some of the challenges ‚Äî like upgrading your bike just enough to make a particular jump ‚Äî were fun without crossing into nonsense. (No, there aren‚Äôt zombie sharks to jump... somehow.)

Now, for the frustrations:

Some missions get repetitive. Not a deal-breaker, but noticeable.

The logic of certain missions is‚Ä¶ questionable. It‚Äôs the zombie apocalypse. The world is dead. And someone wants me to dodge raiders, wolves, cougars, undead everything, just to retrieve his copy of the Bible? No. Absolutely not. Grab another one.

Inconsistent writing at times. A character tells you to leave and never come back‚Ä¶ then two breaths later says they could really use you. Maybe he‚Äôs emotionally damaged. Let‚Äôs assume that, because the alternative is just sloppy writing.

[h2] Review for Days Gone [h2] 

I'll preface this by saying that I originally didn't think much of Days Gone when it was advertised and then suddenly went cold with marketing. I got it as part of PS+ back when I played on PS4. I started, stopped, and then started again because the story got me hooked. So my Tl;Dr for the review is this:

Buy the game. Play it. If it's on sale, play it. It has a fun gameplay loop even if it seems like a typical zombie apocalypse game. There's an arcade-y style feel to it with the level up system too. The strongest part about the game though, is the story. I can't recommend it enough, the best aspect of it is how attached you will get to a few characters because of how well their voice actors performed. 

- [b] Gameplay [b]
- [b] Difficulty [b]


[h2] Gameplay [h2] (Crossbow is love, crossbow is life)

The gameplay is a fun, turn-your-brain off (but not too long) shooter with some light RPG elements associated with it. You get two leveling systems (maybe 4 if you count the bike and the camp trusts). You get one in the form of XP, which unlocks a skill tier for three categories: Melee, Ranged, and Survival. Melee is obvious, increasing your damage with melee weapons and focusing on stamina regen. Ranged focuses on your weapons, and deals with focus regen (this is an upgrade you [i] can [i] get in the MSQ, it's not given to you). Survival has to deal with passive abilities and making the most of surviving in the wild, and deals with health regen. No category overpowers the other--all three of them yield extremely useful skills that will help you survive in combat. Melee has an ability to instantly kill enemies after escaping a grapple, stun weaker enemies with a rock (which then sets them up for an instant kill) or instantly killing some of the more dangerous enemies in the game if you approach them undetected. Ranged gives you better stopping power, accuracy, and extended inventory space. Survival allows you take double the amount of plants, four times the animal meat to sell, and even outlining enemies a certain distance from you, even if they're behind walls. You can't sequence break early--you do have to reach about halfway into the game before you start getting tier 4/5/6 abilities to play with. The other you get in the form of NERO injectors, which permanently increase your Health, Stamina, or Focus for the rest of the game. I did beat the entire game on Hard II as of this review, the upgrades were not necessary to beat the game but they add a fair amount of quality of life to your experience. Overall I find the game very smooth to control and even aiming feel precise without upgrading (to a degree, it depends on the rank of your weapon too). 

Oh yeah. Weapons! You start with a 9mm and Knife (Syphon Filter 2 mission 1, anyone?) and you can loot weapons off of enemies you kill, or in rare cases find them on the field. Your starting pistol is, to put it lightly, trash. No seriously, it's considered junk condition, which means you can't even modify it. Weapons come in five ranks: 

1. Junk
2. Poor
3. Average
4. Military Spec
5. Spec Forces

Junk being the worst, and Spec Forces being the best. You will not see Spec Forces weapons until MUCH later in the game, but some weapons can still carry, like the MWS or US556. The rank determines whether or not you can modify it, and you cannot modify weapons below rank three it seems. Thing is... the "modification" system is almost meaningless because you have duplicate weapons with different ranks. The rank also affects the overall stats of the weapon, so the only modification you can do to them aside from a suppressor is giving an extended mag. That's it. Don't get me wrong, you will learn to appreciate having a lot of bullets in this game, because ammo is scarce for a decent chunk of it. You can loot police cars or enemy camps, but you can only hold so many bullets until you upgrade/modify. 

Melee weapons technically have no rank, and are instead displayed to you based on how much damage vs. durability they have. There are objectively superior melee weapons though, namely crafted ones. Don't expect something out of Dead Rising 2 though, Deacon is not skilled enough to make crazy stuff like that. They are handy to have when you want to neutralize freakers without firing your gun or using up suppressor durability, because sound is REALLY important in this game. It's a reoccurring factor throughout the entire game, to the point that the game will sometimes warn you of either more or extremely strong enemies spawning because too much noise is being made. This applies to both you and hostile human enemies. You will unlock more dangerous enemies that will start spawning in the overworld once you do specific MSQs. 

You have access to a crafting system. There are some items which look like they can be interacted with, but can't be until later in the game OR when you earn the requisite recipe. Those items function as materials to craft a slew of things: from proximity bombs, to smoke bombs, to sound attractors for freakers, to molotovs, to the aforementioned crafted weapons. There's a sizable chunk here, and some of that even pertains to recovery items. I think having a small crafting list was for the best--I couldn't really think of anything that you couldn't already craft or use with the crossbow. Crossbow is love, crossbow is life. Seriously, that crossbow is so damn handy in the later half of the game. You will make friends with cedar saplings and you'll like it. 9/10 for gameplay.

[h2] Difficulty [h2] (Be a chad and do a fresh Survival II run on permadeath)

The game comes with several difficulties:

- Easy
- Normal (1st time completion)
- Hard
- Hard II (2nd time completion)
- Survival 
- Survival II 

Going from Normal to Hard II is like going from playing baseball in high school to playing in the Major Leagues where if you get three strikes, your life is forfeit. Ok, it's not THAT bad, but it still is a sizable step up in difficulty. On normal enemies are like pillows. On Hard II, Freakers and their variants, along with wild animals are very tanky. It's not too obnoxious as you can line up headshots, but some enemies take more than just a few mag dump headshots. I will note that I had permanent upgrades due to challenge mode, you get patches added to Deacon's character model for every one you earn (which is a nice touch) and the efficacy of them depends on what rank you got for each sub challenge. I'll avoid going into challenge mode, but you can reap those benefits for story mode if you know what you're doing. Shame we can't use the rings, though. Getting back to enemy difficulty, on Hard II you cannot mark enemies via binoculars, and enemies are far more quick to spot you from a distance as well as flank you out of cover more often. But what really sucks about this is that enemies never dynamically scale with you, only Freakers. From beginning till the end you will still fight the same squatters and drifters using rank 1 and rank 2 weapons. Only one other faction aside from one you encounter in MSQ has access to rank 2 and some rank 3 weapons. Personally, I would have liked if enemies got stronger weapons in accordance to your level+weapons bought. Would have added a little bit of variety. 7.5-8/10.

I can't express how truly disappointing this game is. Reading the reviews is honestly shocking by how many people say "this is the best game ever" and compare it to RDR2 or The Last Of Us. In my opinion, this doesn't even come close to those games. To be clear, I enjoy zombie games, especially ones with a good story, and motorcycle games like GTA IV's The Lost and Dammed, but I would rather replay any of the titles mentioned above rather than this game.

PROS (and some cons):
The best part of the game is fighting the zombie hordes, it's fun to fight them and it does take some strategy to win against the larger hordes - but the zombie types (Screamer, Breaker, Runner) are uninspired and do not provoke any real challenge, besides being overwhelmed by them in the hundreds. The guns lack oomph and feel clunky to shoot, and fighting the human enemies gets old quick. 

Riding around on your bike is fun, but only until you're able to upgrade it enough that you can get decent speed and a fuel tank that doesn't require being refilled every five minutes. It's tedious in the beginning but will get better as you progress.

The graphics and atmosphere are good, but without missions or a main task to direct you, it feels very empty and exploring the world eventually becomes dull. Picking flowers, hunting animals, and reading memorial plaques can only keep you entertained for so long. 

CONS:
The main character (Deacon) is an emotionally stunted war veteran motorcycle loving tough-guy who can't get over his dead wife and spends all his time with his beer/shotgun loving MC buddy (Boozer) who is just as unlikable and emotionally awkward as Deacon. Throughout the story you learn that they are good guys, but they constantly act like a-holes and refuse to accept help from anyone (even each other) or talk about their emotions because they're so "tough, hard, and badass" that even showing a speck of weakness would be too much for them to handle. Deacon refuses to talk about his trauma and is constantly telling everyone to "Shut up" or "Drop it" when they try to talk to him about it, and the game prefers to show you pieces of his personality through flashbacks or random moments where he feels the need to save a helpless woman so he can look like a white knight.

Aside from the bugs and glitches, my biggest gripe is how boring, predictable and cheesy the storyline is + the AWFUL voice acting. I am a big fan of Sam Witwer and I think he does great work - but the direction they gave him was horrendous and I cringe at how some of his lines are delivered. The characters lack so much depth, making it very difficult to connect emotionally with any of them. So far, the only character I've genuinely liked is Boozer's dog (Jack). 

This game is not awful, but it's decent at best. If you're looking to buy, wait until a sale and I would not pay more than $15 max. If you're looking to kill time and want to try something new, go for it, but don't expect it to blow your expectations out of the water.

i was intrigued when play station games started coming on pc and after playing the new god of war games, which i really enjoyed, i was ready to give more sony published games a chance. and since both survival horror and zombie games are genres i enjoy, i decided to start with days gone. all'n all not a horrible game, but the thing is it's barely a game, it's more like a long movie with playable cut scenes.

 the crafting system, if you can call it that, is lacking, half baked and redundant at the same time. the only thing that keeps you looting for things is the artificial cap on the amount of crafting components which you can carry which is btw ridiculous, like even after fully levelling up you can barely carry enough scrap to repair your melee weapon twice. speaking of levelling, its just like the crafting system, i'm certain if they would just remove levelling altogether, it would be an improvement to the game. the gun play is possibly the most generic (and i'm being kind) i have ever seen in a game ( guns have no weight, sound awful to shoot, aiming and handling are at best jank,etc); games like dead island and dying light which are meant to be primarily melee focused games, have way more engaging fire arm mechanics. and again with the artificial ammo limitation, the gun play just feels awful. like you'r telling me i can have only 5 sniper bullets at a time. and it's not like the melee is good either. honestly the only game play mechanic i liked was riding a bike, that's kinda telling that in an action adventure zombie game, that's the best quality. and to top it all off, most enemies you fight with and the majority of the story line is not even about zombies, it's all humans, to the point many time i genuinely forgot zombies even existed in the game.
to sum it up, there is no game play. as i said it's for most parts a long movie. now that being said, it's not even a good movie, the sound tracks and music is serviceable and graphics i think is the highlight of the game. but you would think the "game" would have if not a good story, at least an engaging one. and there is a difference, i've seen plenty of movies and played games which i did not like the story of, for a variety of reasons yet still followed and engaged with. but here, it's just plain boring, and i don't mean geology documentary boring, i mean back of the math class 9 am algebra with the substitute teacher who barely speaks your language boring. like i could not even bring myself to dislike the story; i was so bored out of my mind i stopped playing at what i guess would be considered as the climax of the game, when the truth is unravelled to the protagonist and the stakes are highest. and let me tell you something, when i start a game i play it at the very least to the end of the main quest, i can not think of a single other game that i played halfway through and stopped, even if i hated it, if for nothing to at least see it end. there's more i can say about the game, like how it basically lies to you at the beginning, letting you think your choices matter with the camps or side activities like hunting are going to be a fun and rewarding part of the game, but i think i have wasted enough of my time with this game.
worst part is that i got the game on a 20% discount and thought of it as a good deal. 
if you are looking for an extremely boring, poorly written and long zombie movie; i still would not suggest this, go watch zombie land.

For me this was an utter disappointment. They went for a self serious tone similar to The Last Of Us but when combined with the goofy ass, borderline childish dialogue, and flimsy, unsatisfying gameplay, it just didn't work at for me at all. Even a tiny bit of self awareness would've gone a long way here. The dead pan delivery of the main character can only work in a game that is equally serious or if it is being done satirically. The game was also bug ridden as hell. Couldn't go 10 minutes without some wacky physics issue flipping my bike into the sky or some dialogue being out of sync or a character speaking too quickly over another character's dialogue.

I'd list every issue with the game but honestly there are so many that I just can't be bothered to spend my time on it. I'll have spent more time on this review than the game itself. I guess one positive I can say for the game is the performance was [i]okay[/i]. Not incredible, but okay outside of a stutter here and there. And the horde mechanics (which I am yet to experience) looks pretty solid from what I've seen in trailers and in gameplay footage. In my 3 hours played I didn't get to a point where a horde came except for one in a cutscene. Outside of those few things, I really have nothing good to say about this game.
